text:
Many customers have applications that require
single-digit millisecond latency to end-users

such as real-time gaming, media &
entertainment content creation, AR/VR
engineering simulations, and hybrid migrations

When an AWS Region isnâ€™t close enough
to meet these latency requirements

customers have to provision their
own infrastructure, manage it

and use different APIs or tools to build and run their applications
than what they would otherwise use in the AWS Cloud

Now with AWS Local Zones, you can easily run applications
that need single-digit millisecond latency closer to end-users
and on-premises systems in a specific geographic area

AWS Local Zones are a type of AWS infrastructure
deployment that places AWS compute

storage, database, and other select services close
to large population, industry, and IT centers.

With Local Zones you can run your latency-sensitive applications
using AWS offerings in geographic proximity to end-users

Local Zones provide a consistent experience with AWS Regions,
and you can continue to use familiar and powerful AWS services

to manage, secure, and scale your applications like
CloudFormation, Identity and Access Management (IAM)
CloudTrail and Auto Scaling
You can also consume services such as DynamoDB, S3

and others in the parent Region in the same
way as you do in standard AWS Regions today

AWS Local Zones are managed and
supported by AWS, bringing you all of the
elasticity, scalability, and security benefits of the cloud

You can easily use AWS to build and deploy latency-sensitive
applications closer to your end-users
scale them up or down

and pay only for the resources you use,
giving you a consistent AWS experience.

You can start using Local Zones with just a few steps in the
Amazon EC2 management console or command line interface

Enable the Local Zone(s) of interest, extend your
Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) to the AWS Local Zone

then launch EC2 instances, EBS volumes,
and other services to run your applications

Just like in AWS Regions,
you can set up an Internet Gateway to access
your local resources in the Local Zone over the internet

or you can use AWS Direct Connect to route your
traffic over a private network connection
from any Direct Connect location to the Local Zone

To learn more about AWS Local Zones,
please visit the feature page linked below
https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/global-infrastructure/localzones/
